description: Jamie Dieterle, owner of Revive Boutique, said support from customers online was incredible during the last couple months, and it was great to see so many people coming in today. UOI Boutique in Sterling and Asterisk Boutique in Dixon also opened. Sonia Robinson, owner of Primitive Frills in downtown Sterling, said they were blessed to be able to stay open and had a...
text:
DIXON  Small businesses throughout the area were happy to see customers come
through their doors for the first time in 2 and a half months.

Entering Phase 3 of the governor's Restore Illinois plan meant retail shops
could open while following guidelines including social distancing, wearing
masks, and regularly cleaning surfaces and washing hands.

Jamie Dieterle, owner of Revive Boutique, said support from customers online
was incredible during the last couple months, and it was great to see so many
people coming in today.

"You can tell that people are excited to shop," she said. "I'm thankful to get
to opened back up."

UOI Boutique in Sterling and Asterisk Boutique in Dixon also opened.

Kaleel's Clothing & Printing opened up its doors and took advantage of the
pleasant weather with a sidewalk sale.

Craft shops were also busy welcoming back customers. Sonia Robinson, owner of
Primitive Frills in downtown Sterling, said they were blessed to be able to
stay open and had a steady flow of customers on reopening day.

"We were very happy to have our doors open and have our happy customers come
back in," she said. "It just felt good."

Businesses are resuming normal hours or instituting temporary ones, and some
are still doing services like curbside pickup, special hours for the elderly,
and individual appointments.

"I feel like a giddy school girl," said Grace Crowe, owner of Stone Bridge
Running.

Shoppers should check businesses on Facebook for special hours or
restrictions.

"The Sauk Valley area is a strong community, and they do a good job with
supporting local businesses," Dieterle said.

title: Small businesses thankful for support on reopening day
html:
DIXON – Small businesses throughout the area were happy to see customers come through their doors for the first time in 2 and a half months.

Entering Phase 3 of the governor's Restore Illinois plan meant retail shops could open while following guidelines including social distancing, wearing masks, and regularly cleaning surfaces and washing hands.

Jamie Dieterle, owner of Revive Boutique, said support from customers online was incredible during the last couple months, and it was great to see so many people coming in today.

"You can tell that people are excited to shop," she said. "I'm thankful to get to opened back up."

UOI Boutique in Sterling and Asterisk Boutique in Dixon also opened.

Kaleel's Clothing & Printing opened up its doors and took advantage of the pleasant weather with a sidewalk sale.

Craft shops were also busy welcoming back customers. Sonia Robinson, owner of Primitive Frills in downtown Sterling, said they were blessed to be able to stay open and had a steady flow of customers on reopening day.

"We were very happy to have our doors open and have our happy customers come back in," she said. "It just felt good."

Businesses are resuming normal hours or instituting temporary ones, and some are still doing services like curbside pickup, special hours for the elderly, and individual appointments.

"I feel like a giddy school girl," said Grace Crowe, owner of Stone Bridge Running.

Shoppers should check businesses on Facebook for special hours or restrictions.

"The Sauk Valley area is a strong community, and they do a good job with supporting local businesses," Dieterle said.
